instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3023: What is 820-3023? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.R7151: What is R7151? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
Hello
<SIGNAL>PP_3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> ok
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> ok
I have examined the power supply circuit of the 5v and the 3v3
starting from <CAPACITOR>C9487</CAPACITOR> up to <CHIP>U7101</CHIP> and pin 25.
in both I find the voltage unstable, can the defect be <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
What are you checking on thunderbolt power rail (<CAPACITOR>C9487</CAPACITOR>), if board doesn't even turn on?
No relation at all with <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> (<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>).

Do you get correct <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>?
What is the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage (no battery connected)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3,34 V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>= the voltage is unstable
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>= 8.40 V no battery connected

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> comes on, stable?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> unstable equal

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> fluctuating in the same manner as <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: exact

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
Power cycles every 3-5s, or how?
Do you note pulse on other big coils?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: up and down fast also on L7260

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
You've already said that before; L7260 mis for <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>.
I expected some indication about L7220.

Check for short on all big coils.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: L7220 and 0 I measured <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and accidentally short circuited two pins now <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and 2.34v Maybe I created problems with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, pp3v3 no longer pulsates, I'm still a beginner

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
Always choose surrounding components as test points.
Avoid such problems touching directly chip pins.

Post diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and L7220/60; red probe on ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: L7220 has low insulation 0.002

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
That means short to ground on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>.
Do you have the same value at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?
If yes, <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> is also shorted (D-S).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: I found a hole on <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> and replace it on L8220 I don't have low insulation. I removed F7040 to see the short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, but now I get 3.24v is it not that I have to replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>? One last question, I found <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> on a SIZ710DT donor card only that instead of 17W, there is 15W I have to check the data sheet or well the same?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
No problem, if pads layout is the same for both.

Did you check if <TRANSISTOR>Q7220</TRANSISTOR> is shorted D-S?
Changing <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> doesn't eliminate the short to ground from L7220.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: So, I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> and pp3v3 returned <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> also returned to normal value, on L7220 I found <CAPACITOR>C7252</CAPACITOR> with low insulation. But is <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> normal for it to be very hot? Or did I create problems with it? Now I only have 5V S3 to restore

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1800</CHIP> is the PCH and shouldn't get very hot in off state.
Very likely the PCH is dead now; because of <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> overvoltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: But by whom is the overvoltage caused? Can't I do anything?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
Guess what happened when <TRANSISTOR>Q7260</TRANSISTOR> got burnt.
If PCH gets very hot now, when only 3V power rails are available on the board, then is dead.

As board is in off state, only RTC and system power management blocks of PCH are powered up.
No reason at all to get even warm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: But without the PCH I will never get the 5V S3? Can I interrupt the 3v3s that go to the PCH get the 5V somehow and then replace the PCH? Otherwise I give up

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> is controlled by PCH, via <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>; as any other S3 voltage.
You can force <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> power supply, but what do you expect?
PCH is dead...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: So the next move could be to change the PCH?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
If you still have short on <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> power rail, should be better to find it first.
Also check for short on other power rails.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: I eliminated the short by replacing <CAPACITOR>C7252</CAPACITOR> I checked after L7220 and the low insulation disappeared but still nothing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> probably because of the PCH if I understood correctly

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: Yes, PCH doesn't enable S3 power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: Just out of curiosity, what do you mean by forcing <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
Forcing its enable signal, instead of using <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> from PCH.
Remove <RESISTOR>R7913</RESISTOR> and check L7220 voltage.
If no volt, run a wire from <RESISTOR>R7251</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R7252</RESISTOR> abd test again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: Removing <RESISTOR>R7913</RESISTOR> The PCH is no longer hot, it also disappeared <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> then I joined <RESISTOR>R7151</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7252</RESISTOR> but on L7220 always 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> power rail is enabled through <RESISTOR>R7941</RESISTOR>.
Removing <RESISTOR>R7913</RESISTOR> forces <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and probably <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> detects a fault on this rail and disables both outputs.

All this doesn't have much sense if you don't want to change PCH...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Power not charge
threads.message: I found one that equals <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> A but has a low insulation on L7330, as you advise me to proceed
